questions.text: A 3-week-old neonate presents with jaundice. He has clay-colored stools and hepatomegaly. Ultrasound is performed, and the obtained image is shown below. What is the name of the ultrasound finding?
questions.solution:
The 3-week-old neonate with persistent jaundice, clay-colored stool, and hepatomegaly is likely to have biliary atresia. The ultrasound confirms the diagnosis by demonstrating the triangular cord sign. 

The triangular cord sign represents the cone-shaped fibrotic mass cranial to the bifurcation of the portal vein. This density is echogenic and represents the fibrous remains of the porta hepatis. 

Biliary atresia may also be termed as noncystic obliterative cholangiopathy. It is a disease of the intra and extrahepatic bile ducts of unknown etiology.

The classification of biliary atresia with the regions involved is as follows:

  • Type I - Common bile duct
  • Type IIa - Common hepatic duct
  • Type IIb - Common bile duct, hepatic duct, cystic duct.
  • Type III (most common type)-Common bile duct, hepatic duct, cystic duct; no anastomosable ducts at porta hepatis 

Clinical features include persistent jaundice, clay-colored stools, and hepatomegaly. Untreated newborns will show signs of liver cirrhosis and failure (ascites, portal hypertension, and failure to thrive). 

Laboratory evaluation will show elevated levels of direct and indirect bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, and gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase. Ultrasound will show hypoplastic or absent gall bladder and the triangular cord sign. 

Treatment is surgery via Kasai procedure or liver transplantation. 

Other options: 

Option A - Falciform ligament sign is seen in the case of pneumoperitoneum. Here, the air outlines the appearance of the falciform ligament, as seen in the x-ray below. 


Option C - Double bubble sign occurs due to dilated stomach and duodenum in duodenal atresia. It is seen in x-rays and ultrasound. The following image depicts the double bubble sign. 


Option D - Target sign is seen in infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis and intussusception. The following ultrasound image shows the target sign seen in intussusception.

questions.text:
Match the following skull radiology findings and the associated conditions.
1) Salt and pepper appearance A) Hurler's syndrome
2) J-shaped sella B) Paget's disease
3) Punched-out lesions C) Hyperparathyroidism
4) Cotton wool appearance D) Multiple myeloma
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B.

  • Salt and pepper appearance - Hyperparathyroidism 
  • J-shaped sella - Hurler's syndrome
  • Punched-out lesions - Multiple myeloma
  • Cotton wool appearance - Paget's disease

Salt and pepper appearance of the skull: It is also known as pepper pot skull and is seen in hyperparathyroidism. It is characterized by multiple tiny well-defined lucencies in the skull that occur due to resorption of the trabecular bone.

Other radiological findings in hyperparathyroidism:

  • Sub-periosteal resorption - Classical and pathognomonic feature of hyperparathyroidism
  • Loss of lamina dura 
  • Expansile lytic lesion, otherwise known as brown tumor, generally affecting maxilla/ mandible

Image showing salt and pepper appearance of the skull:

 

J-shaped sella - It is a skull radiographic finding in Hurler's syndrome.

Other radiological findings in Hurler's syndrome:

  • Macrocephaly
  • Thickened calvaria (skull cap)
  • Oar-shaped ribs
  • Hook-shaped vertebral bodies

Note:

J-shaped sella can also be seen in other conditions like optic chiasm glioma, hydrocephalus, neurofibromatosis, as a normal anatomic variant, etc.

Image showing J-shaped sella:

 

Punched-out lesions - It is frequently associated with multiple myeloma. 

Other important causes for punched-out skull lesions include metastatic lesions, tuberculosis, sarcoidosis, epidermoid tumor, fibrous dysplasia, etc.

Image showing punched-out lesions of the skull:

 

Cotton wool appearance - It is seen in Paget's disease of the bone. It refers to the mixed lytic and sclerotic lesions of the skull.

Other skull radiological findings in Paget's disease:

  • Osteoporosis circumscripta - Large well-defined lytic lesions involving the inner part of the outer table of the skull with an intact inner table
  • Diploic widening
  • Tam o' Shanter sign

questions.text: An infant had non-bilious projectile vomiting immediately after feeding, and an olive-shaped mass per abdomen. Sonography was done. All of the following features can be seen in this condition, except _______.
questions.solution:
An infant with non-bilious, projectile vomiting and an olive-shaped mass per abdomen is likely to have congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. On sonography, all of the following can be seen in this condition, except a shortened pyloric canal. The pyloric canal appears elongated with thickened and hypoechoic pyloric muscle.

Ultrasound has high sensitivity and specificity. It is the investigation of choice and confirms the diagnosis for most cases of suspected hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. Other sonographic findings include:

  • Hypoechoic thickened pyloric muscle with a hyperechoic central mucosa - Target sign
  • Hypertrophied pylorus resembles the uterine cervix - Cervix sign
  • Hypertrophic muscle bulging into the antrum of a fluid-filled stomach- Shoulder sign
  • Redundant pyloric mucosa protrudes into the antrum- Antral nipple sign 
  • Abnormal, exaggerated peristaltic waves 
  • Pyloric thickness is 3-4 mm, and pyloric length is 15-19 mm

The image below shows a sonographic image of pyloric stenosis showing the antral sign and the cervix sign.

 

Findings on Barium studies:

  • Elongated pyloric channel - String sign
  • Bulging of the pyloric muscle into the antrum - Shoulder sign
  • Parallel streaks of barium in a thin lumen - Double tract sign

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) most commonly presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting. The vomiting is usually progressive and occurs immediately after a feed. As vomiting progresses, loss of fluid, hydrogen ions and chloride ions leads to hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis.

On examination, an olive-shaped mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium. When the infant is given a test feed, visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from across the abdomen, followed by projectile vomiting.

Management involves correcting the fluid, acid-base, and electrolyte losses initially. It is then treated surgically by performing a pyloromyotomy.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases are incorrectly matched with their imaging modality of choice?

choices.text: Hirschsprung’s disease- Plain x-ray abdomen with air contrast
Neonatal hepatitis- Nuclear medicine; hepatobiliary scintigraphy

questions.solution:
The imaging modality of choice in Hirschsprung's disease is a contrast radiograph with barium or gastrografin enema. 

The most important film is a lateral or oblique view of the rectum during slow filling. It typically shows a low bowel obstruction. The rectum is seen as a narrow tube and a cone-shaped transition zone, seen proximal to the dilated ganglionated bowel. 

 

Other options:

Transfontanel cranial ultrasonography or a neurosonogram reliably delineates ventricular size and anatomy in neonates. It is an excellent primary imaging technique for the evaluation of the many clinical problems related to ventricular dilatation. 

  1. Ventriculomegaly
  2. Differentiating nonobstructive ventricular dilatation from obstructive enlargement (hydrocephalus)
  3. Cause of hydrocephalus
  4. Temporary management of patients with hydrocephalus
  5. Aiding in the management of patients with permanent ventricular shunts

Ultrasound in pyloric stenosis will show a dilated, fluid-filled stomach and proximal duodenum with obstruction. A coexisting volvulus can show as a whirlpool sign. 

Hepatobiliary scintigraphy is a radionuclide imaging that shows metabolic activity in different cell types based on the substance taken up by the various cells.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who is in her 12th week of gestation was referred to you by an obstetrician for sonographic evaluation. You notice the following sign on USG. Identify the sign and the type of twin gestation it indicates.
questions.solution:
The image shows the lambda sign or twin peak sign seen in dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy.

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick septum between the two gestational sacs.

A triangular projection is seen at the base of the membrane. This is known as lambda or twin peak sign. The presence of lambda or twin peak sign indicates a dichorionic placenta.

The "T sign" seen in sonographic images signifies a monochorionic twin pregnancy, where there is a lack of chorion extending between the layers of the intertwin membrane.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: Shown below is the pelvic ultrasound image of a 28-year-old female patient with a positive urine pregnancy test. She gave a history of recent treatment for infertility. Identify the classical radiological finding shown in her right adnexa.
questions.solution:
The image shows the bagel sign seen in tubal ectopic pregnancy.

The bagel sign is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of a gestational sac in the adnexa with a hyperechoic ring. It is characteristic of tubal ectopic pregnancy. This sign has a positive predictive value of 95% in ectopic pregnancy. 

A normal corpus luteum can also mimic this sign but can be differentiated by a bimanual pelvic examination.

questions.text:
Which of the following can be classified as ionizing radiation?
  1. Alpha rays
  2. Beta rays
  3. Gamma rays
  4. X-rays
  5. MRI
questions.solution:
Among the given options, alpha rays, beta rays, gamma rays, and x-rays are ionizing radiations. MRI is an example of non-ionizing electromagnetic radiation. 

Ionizing radiation is a type of radiation with enough energy to remove tightly bound electrons from the orbit of an atom, causing the atom to be charged or ionized. They can be either directly ionizing or indirectly ionizing. Alpha rays and beta rays are directly ionizing radiation because they carry a charge and can directly interact with atomic electrons. Alpha and beta rays are also particulate radiation (composed of particles). 

Gamma rays and x-rays are electromagnetic rays. They are indirectly ionizing radiation as they are electrically neutral and do not interact directly with electrons. 

MRI is a technique that produces topographic images by means of magnetic fields and radiofrequency waves. It uses non-ionizing electromagnetic radiation. MRI is based on the ability of nuclei of certain atoms to absorb and emit radio wave energy when the body is placed within a strong magnetic field.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents with complaints of dull, aching headaches and difficulty seeing the class board for the past few months. He is below the 25th percentile for height and weight. Deep tendon reflexes are sluggish. Eye examination reveals papilledema and bitemporal hemianopsia. An MRI shows a mixed cystic and solid lesion in the suprasellar region with calcification. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette of a calcified cystic lesion in the suprasellar region and symptoms of headache with bitemporal hemianopsia is suggestive of craniopharyngioma. 

It is a benign tumor that is derived from Rathke’s pouch, a diverticulum arising from the embryonic buccal cavity, from which the anterior pituitary gland develops. It is most commonly seen in children (5–15 years); however, it exhibits a bimodal incidence and can also be seen in adults (55–65 years). 

These tumors are usually large and heterogeneous and have both solid and cystic components and occur within the suprasellar area. The cysts contain a cholesterol-rich, thick, brownish-yellow fluid that is comparable to "machine oil."

Clinical presentation:

  • Features of raised intracranial pressure, including headache that is a continuous dull-aching type and papilledema
  • Visual impairment, with decreased acuity or visual field abnormalities (bitemporal hemianopsia)
  • Endocrinologic abnormalities, such as growth failure, hypothyroidism, and delayed sexual maturation due to pituitary hypofunction

Radiological findings:   

  • CT: May show calcifications associated with the solid and cystic wall components.
  • MRI: 
Cysts
T1 Iso- to hyperintense to the brain (due to high protein content "machinery oil cysts")
T2 Mostly hyperintense
Solid component
T1  Vivid enhancement
T2  Variable or mixed

Other options: 

Option B- Pituitary macroadenomas (with cystic degeneration or necrosis) usually have an intrasellar epicenter with pituitary fossa enlargement rather than suprasellar epicenter. Calcifications are mostly absent, in contrast to craniopharyngiomas. In addition, on imaging, indentation at the diaphragma sellae gives rise to snowman/figure of eight appearance/cottage loaf.

Option C- Optic nerve gliomas can be seen involving the optic nerves, optic chiasm, and optic tracts and can be differentiated from craniopharyngiomas with the help of calcifications that are characteristically seen in the latter. They are a type of pilocytic astrocytes that occur in childhood.

Option D- Rathke's cleft cysts appear completely cystic with a smooth, thin wall and no calcifications on MRI. They are mostly seen in the intrasellar region; this is in contrast to craniopharyngiomas, which are mostly suprasellar.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented with anorexia, weight loss, and anemia. Endoscopy revealed a gastric ulcer.  Which of the following barium study finding in this patient is suggestive of a malignant gastric ulcer?

choices.text: Folds around the ulcer are smooth and even

questions.solution:
The Carman meniscus sign is suggestive of a malignant gastric ulcer.

It is seen in the setting of a large, flat, malignant ulcer with healed-up edges. These edges trap the barium, which gives a convex formation towards the lumen of the stomach. In benign ulcers, it forms a concave shape towards the lumen of the stomach.

The Kirklin complex is a combination of the Carman meniscus sign associated with a radiolucent semi-circular zone surrounding the elevated ridge of the ulcer. This complex is seen in cases of gastric adenocarcinoma in barium studies.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents with 3 months of amenorrhea. She was found to have abnormally high levels of serum β-hCG.  The USG shows the following characteristic appearance. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical scenario and ultrasound image showing a characteristic pattern known as a bunch of grapes/ honeycombed uterus/ snow-storm appearance, the most probable diagnosis is a hydatidiform mole.

Molar pregnancy or hydatidiform mole results from abnormal chromosomal fertilization. It results in trophoblastic proliferation and villous stromal edema forming an immature placenta. It includes the benign complete hydatidiform mole (46XX) and partial hydatidiform mole (69 XXX or 69 XXY). An invasive mole with malignant potential may also occur.

The previous history of molar pregnancy and extremes of reproductive age are the high-risk factors.

Clinically, the female presents with 1-2 months of amenorrhea followed by vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and vomiting. The uterus size exceeds that of the corresponding gestational age. Serum β-hCG levels are raised above those expected for gestational age. 

In a complete mole, the ultrasound imaging shows a uterine mass made of anechoic cystic masses without a fetus or amniotic sac filling the endometrial cavity surrounded by normal myometrium. This is described as a “snowstorm” appearance.

In a partial mole, thick, multicystic placenta with minimal hydatidiform changes and some fetal tissues may be seen. A thin septum may be found within the gestational sac.

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

questions.text: An abdominal x-ray of a neonate admitted to NICU is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given abdominal x-ray of the neonate shows the double bubble sign, which is suggestive of duodenal atresia.

Duodenal atresia is the blockade of the duodenum due to the failure of recanalisation during embryonic development from its solid cord stage, leaving the duodenum partially or completely obstructed. It is often associated with trisomy 21/Down syndrome, prematurity, maternal polyhydramnios, cardiac malformations, and malformations of the hepatobiliary system.

The range of anatomic variants includes duodenal stenosis, mucosal web with intact muscle wall (so-called windsock deformity), two ends separated by a fibrous cord, and complete separation with a gap within the duodenum. 

On abdominal X-ray, the double bubble sign represents the dilatation of the stomach and proximal duodenum. This can often be detected prenatally via ultrasound but, if missed, neonates typically present with bilious vomiting shortly after birth, as the obstruction is usually distal to the ampulla of Vater. 

Causes of double bubble sign are congenital obstruction - duodenal atresia (associated with Down syndrome), midgut volvulus, and external compression of the duodenum.

The radiological finding obtained on the barium study is a windsock deformity.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: An alcoholic male patient presents with complaints of acute onset of epigastric pain radiating to the back. Serum amylase and lipase were elevated. Examination revealed the finding shown below. All of the following are the radiological findings associated with this condition, except ______.
questions.solution:
Cullen sign is not a radiological finding associated with this condition. It is a clinical sign seen on abdominal examination.

The clinical presentation of acute onset of epigastric pain radiating to the back, elevated serum amylase and lipase, and the image showing the Grey-Turner sign is suggestive of acute pancreatitis.

Abdominal examination findings in acute pancreatitis:

  • Grey Turner sign: bleeding into the fascial planes leading to bluish discoloration of the flanks
  • Cullen’s sign: bleeding into the fascial planes leading to the bluish discoloration around the umbilicus (image shown below)

 

Radiological x-ray findings in acute pancreatitis:

Sentinel loop sign - It refers to the generalized or localized ileus of the intestine adjacent to the pancreas. A sentinel loop refers to a short segment of adynamic ileus adjacent to an intra-abdominal inflammatory process.

Colon cut-off sign - It occurs as a result of colonic spasm at the splenic flexure. This would result in gaseous distension of the proximal colon with the abrupt termination of the gas at the level of splenic flexure and decompression of the more distal part of the colon.

Renal halo sign - It is produced by the apparent enhancement of the perirenal fat by an adjacent retroperitoneal exudate in the pararenal space.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in Acute Pancreatitis

Radiographic findings of acute pancreatitis are non-specific.

The sentinel loop is seen in an X-ray. It is a focal area of adynamic ileus close to an intra-abdominal inflammatory process. A sentinel loop in the upper abdomen indicates pancreatitis.

The sentinel loop sign may aid in localizing the source of inflammation. For example, a sentinel loop in the upper abdomen may indicate pancreatitis, while one in the right lower quadrant may be due to appendicitis.

Colon cut-off sign: Functional spasm at the splenic flexure due to the extension of inflammation to phrenicocolic ligament via transverse mesocolon.

  • Localised ground-glass appearance

questions.text:
A 38-year-old female patient presents with a history of fever and cough for 10 days. On examination, the pulse is 96 bpm, BP is 118/70 mmHg, the temperature is 100.4 °F, RR is 15/min and SpO2 is 96%. Laboratory reports are awaited. Chest CT, as shown below, demonstrates ground-glass opacities close to the visceral pleural surfaces and visible intralobular lines. Which CO-RADS category does this patient fall under?

CO-RADS - COVID-19 Reporting and Data System
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation is highly suspicious of COVID-19. The chest CT findings of ground-glass opacities near the visceral pleural line and crazy paving place this patient under CO-RADS 5 (COVID-19 Reporting and Data System).

CO-RADS 5 implies a very high level of suspicion for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19 based on typical CT findings. It requires the presence of at least one confirmatory pattern. 

Typical features for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19:

Obligatory features:

  • Ground-glass opacities, with or without consolidation, in regions close to the visceral pleural lines, including the fissures
  • Multifocal bilateral distribution

Confirmatory patterns:

  • Ground-glass regions
    • Unsharp, rounded shape
    • Sharp demarcation, outlining the shape of multiple adjacent pulmonary lobules
  • Crazy paving 
  • Patterns compatible with organizing pneumonia
  • Thickened vessels within parenchymal abnormalities 

CO-RADS uses a five-point scale to report suspicion for pulmonary involvement of COVID-19 on chest CT. The CO-RADS categories are as follows:

CO-RADS 0: Not interpretable, and technically insufficient to assign a score 

CO-RADS 1: Very low level of suspicion for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19. CT findings are normal or of unequivocal non-infectious etiology; e.g. mild or severe emphysema, perifissural nodules, lung tumors, or fibrosis

CO-RADS 2: Low level of suspicion for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19; includes infectious etiology that is not compatible with COVID-19 such as bronchitis, bronchiolitis, bronchopneumonia, lobar pneumonia, and abscess

CO-RADS 3: Equivocal findings for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19; findings overlap with other infectious etiologies; could include perihilar ground-glass, homogenous extensive ground-glass, with or without sparing of secondary pulmonary lobules

CO-RADS 4: High level of suspicion for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19; findings are similar to those of CO-RADS 5 but are not present in the typical locations; findings may also be superimposed on severe pre-existing pulmonary abnormalities 

CO-RADS 5: Very high level of suspicion for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19 based on typical CT findings mentioned above

CO-RADS 6: Proven COVID-19 by positive RT-PCR test.

On chest x-ray PA view, right cardiac border is formed by _______.

1. Superior vena cava
2. Inferior vena cava
3. Right atrium
4. Right ventricle
questions.solution:
On a chest x-ray PA view,

Right cardiac border formed by

  • Superior vena cava (SVC)
  • Right atrium
  • Inferior vena cava (IVC)

Left cardiac border formed by

  • Subclavian artery
  • Aortic knuckle
  • Pulmonary artery segment
  • Left atrial appendage
  • Left ventricle

Posteroanterior view (PA view) is the most commonly done chest x-ray view.

PA view is usually done in full inspiration and standing position.

Ideally, there should be no rotation. If there is no rotation, the distance between the medial end of the clavicle and the spinous process will be equidistant, on both sides. 

In a normal chest x-ray, the left dome of the diaphragm is lower than the right because the heart pushes the left dome down.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident, and an eFAST was performed. What is the additional view that is not possible with FAST but is possible with eFAST?
questions.solution:
Focussed Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (FAST) is extended into the thoracic cavities and peri­cardium (eFAST), where anterior pleural views are incorporated. It is a technique in which ultrasonography is used to assess the presence of free fluid in the abdominal cavity. 

It is a rapid, non-invasive bedside test for detecting free fluid in the abdomen using sonography, used to assess patients for potential thoracoabdominal injuries. 

The patient is placed in a supine position. The following regions are scanned:

  • Subxiphoid transverse view (also called subcostal view or pericardial view)
  • Right upper quadrant view (also called right flank view or perihepatic view)
  • Left upper quadrant view (also called perisplenic or left flank view) 
  • Suprapubic view or pelvic view

An extended FAST or eFAST scan incorporates the anterior pleural views to assess the anterior thorax.

Drawbacks of FAST:

  • Does not reliably detect less than 100 mL of free blood
  • Does not directly identify hollow viscus injury or penetrating trauma
  • Often requires supplementing with other investigations
  • Does not assess the retroperitoneum

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida has come for an antenatal ultrasound examination. The sonographic image obtained is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the lemon sign, which is seen in spina bifida.

Spina bifida is the common open neural tube defect associated with hydrocephalus and Arnold-Chiari II malformation. It is the most common open neural tube disorder. Spina bifida is characterized by a cleft in the vertebral column with a corresponding defect in the skin so that the meninges and spinal cord are exposed.

The 3 main types of spina bifida:

  • Spina bifida occulta - This is the mildest form of spina bifida. The defect in the vertebral arches is covered by the skin. The splits in the vertebrae are so small that the spinal cord does not protrude. The skin at the site of the lesion may be normal, or it may have some hair growing from it.
  • Meningocele - The defect in the vertebra allows the meninges to protrude through the defect.
  • Myelomeningocele (meningomyelocele) - A defect in the vertebral column allows the spinal cord with the meningeal coverings to protrude. 

The lemon sign is related to changes in the configuration of the fetal frontal bone, which loses convexity and appears concave or linear on ultrasonography; this sign can be detected during the first six months of gestation.

The banana sign is another sign that is seen in spina bifida associated with Arnold-Chiari II malformation. Herniation of the brainstem and cerebellar tonsils occurs through the foramen magnum, with the cerebellum surrounding the brainstem, thus giving rise to the appearance of the curved shape of a banana.

Other options: 

Option B: Anencephaly is characterized by an open defect in the calvaria and skin, such that the cranial neural tube is exposed. It is a severe defect and is not compatible with survival. Frog eye sign is seen in USG. Prominent orbits (arrows) and an absence of cerebral tissue more cranially are seen.

Option C: Holoprosencephaly is a rare congenital brain malformation resulting from incomplete separation of the two hemispheres. On antenatal ultrasound, there may be also evidence of polyhydramnios, and the snake-under-the-skull sign may also be seen.

Option D: Omphalocele is a midline anterior abdominal wall defect through which the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel may herniate. The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac. Given below is a fetal ultrasound image suggestive of an omphalocele (asterisk).

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A 34-year-old  male patient presents to the emergency department with acute onset of severe abdominal pain. The patient gives a history of recurrent episodes of epigastric pain and burning sensation for the past few months. The supine abdominal radiograph of the patient is given below. What is the characteristic sign shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The above x-ray shows the presence of air in the bilateral subphrenic spaces and a linear density on the ventral surface of the liver (arrow), known as the falciform ligament sign. It is seen in the pneumoperitoneum. 

The acute presentation of abdominal pain with similar episodes in the past, along with the given abdomen x-ray suggests pneumoperitoneum. Bilateral subphrenic free air is seen and the arrow mark shown here is the falciform ligament. This peritoneal fold is an embryological remnant of the umbilical artery connecting the anterior abdominal wall to the anterosuperior surface of the liver. It is invisible under normal situations; however, when surrounded by intraperitoneal free air, it may become visible as a vertical band of soft tissue parallel to the right border of the spine.

Causes of pneumoperitoneum:

  • Bowel perforation
    1. Peptic ulcer
    2. Ischemic bowel
    3. Necrotizing enterocolitis
  • Small bowel perforation
    1. Trauma
    2. Penetrating injuries
  • Injury during surgery/laparoscopy

Radiological signs in pneumoperitoneum:

  • Bowel-related signs
    • Double-wall sign (also known as Rigler's sign): Both the outer and inner walls of the bowel are visible.
    • Telltale triangle sign (also known as triangle sign): A radiolucent triangle of gas between three loops of bowel or between two loops of bowel and the abdominal wall.
  • Peritoneal ligament–related signs
    • Football sign - the abdominal cavity is outlined by gas from a perforated viscus, seen in massive pneumoperitoneum.
    • Falciform ligament sign - Falciform or medial umbilical ligaments may be seen due to free gas on either side of the ligaments. 
    • Lateral umbilical ligament sign (also known as inverted "V" sign) - Free gas routines the lateral umbilical ligament.
    • Urachus sign
  • Right upper quadrant signs
    • Morison's pouch sign - a triangular area of gas in the right upper quadrant, usually bound by the 11th rib in the right upper quadrant in the area of Morrison's pouch
    • Cupola sign - Gas under the right and left hemidiaphragm joining in the midline, seen on chest x-ray.
    • Fissure for ligamentum teres sign
    • Hepatic edge sign
    • Lucent liver sign
    • Periportal free gas sign

Other options: 

Football sign - Supine radiograph where the peritoneal layer is enhanced over the entire abdominal cavity. This is seen in a large pneumoperitoneum. 

Cupola sign - Free air below central tendon of the diaphragm in the midline

Lateral umbilical ligament sign (or inverted 'V' sign) is seen in the pelvis representing free gas outlining the lateral umbilical ligaments.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient was brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident. The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score was E2 V2 M4 when he was brought to the casualty. After a few hours, it became E1 V1 M3. On examination, there are no fractures and no signs of hydrocephalus or raised intracranial pressure. MRI of the patient is shown below.  What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the MRI are suggestive of diffuse axonal injury.

The given image is an axial T2 -weighted MR image demonstrating numerous foci of diffusion restriction, at the grey-white matter junction denoting petechial hemorrhages. It is suggestive of diffuse axonal injury.

Diffuse axonal injury (white matter shearing) is the result of shearing forces, typically from rotational acceleration.

Diffuse axonal injury is characterized by multiple focal lesions with a characteristic distribution:

  • Typically located at the grey-white matter junction, in the corpus callosum, and in more severe cases in the brainstem.
  • CT may be normal.
  • MRI is the modality of choice for assessing suspected diffuse axonal injury even in patients with entirely normal CT of the brain.
  • MRI, especially SWI (Susceptibility weighted imaging) or GRE (Gradient echo) sequences demonstrates small regions of susceptibility artefact at the grey-white matter junction, in the corpus callosum or the brain stem. 

Other options: 

CT showing intraventricular hemorrhage

CT scan showing cerebral contusions, hemorrhage within the hemispheres, and subdural hematoma on the left.

Related Pearl: Diffuse Axonal Injury

The mechanism of diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is primarily a non-impact rotational acceleration-deceleration injury. This leads to the deformation of the axons by stretching them.

Pathology of DAI:

  • Changes in permeability of the axolemma
  • Axonal swelling
  • Intracellular calcium accumulation
  • Proteolysis
  • The collapse of the cytoskeleton
  • 'Retraction balls or globes' - bulbous and clubbed axons. Seen earliest at 12-18 hours. The number of retraction balls begins to decrease after 2-3 weeks after injury and a cluster of microglial cells appears followed by astrocytosis and demyelination.
  • Immuno-histochemistry shows beta-amyloid precursor protein - the most reliable indicator of axon damage. Seen earliest at 2-3 hours.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presented with 6 months history of postprandial fullness, bloating, abdominal pain, and recurrent episodes of non-bloody diarrhea. A barium study was done and the image is given below. The image shows a sign consistent with Crohn's disease. Identify the sign.
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are of Crohn's disease and the barium study image shows the string sign of Kantor. It refers to a narrowed length of the terminal ileum.

Crohn's disease is a type of inflammatory bowel disease. It presents with symptomatic periods of colicky abdominal pain and diarrhea. It is diagnosed mainly with barium contrast studies and endoscopy. CT and MRI may aid in diagnosis.

Some of the radiological findings in Crohn's disease include cobblestone appearance with ulceration, fistulae, enlarged ileocaecal valve, thickening of the valvulae conniventes, stenosis, and asymmetrical involvement with skip lesions. Some named signs include:

  • Aphthous ulcers: Earliest macroscopic finding in the colonic form of Crohn's disease
  • Cobblestone appearance: It is due to the combination of longitudinal and transverse ulcerations separating intact portions of the mucosa. 
  • Kantor string sign: It refers to the long lengths of narrowed terminal ileum seen in long-standing disease.
  • Creeping fat sign: It refers to the widely separated bowel loops due to fibrofatty proliferation.

Findings on CT or MR enterography include:

  • Fat halo sign- submucosal fat deposition
  • Comb sign- engorgement of the vasa recta

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with severe back pain, vomiting, and hypotension. CT findings are given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given CT image shows well-circumscribed lesions with low attenuation (black in colour) that indicate fatty tissue. This is suggestive of renal angiomyolipomas.

Angiomyolipomas (AMLs) are benign tumours that occur sporadically or in association with tuberous sclerosis. It is commonly seen in adults between 30 and 50 years of age, with a female predilection. AMLs predominantly affect the kidneys, though they can occur in other sites such as the liver (a common extra-renal location) and less frequently in the ovary, fallopian tube, spermatic cord, palate, and colon. 

Histologically, angiomyolipomas consist of perivascular epitheloid cells with varying proportions of vascular, immature smooth muscle cells, and fat cells. Patients with AMLs present with flank pain, a palpable mass, hematuria, recurrent urinary tract infections, hypertension, or renal failure. Larger tumours increase the risk of complications, such as spontaneous retroperitoneal hemorrhage, which can manifest as sudden-onset abdominal or flank pain, along with symptoms like nausea, vomiting, and hypotension.

Everolimus is used for the treatment of angiomyolipomas. Treatment should be considered for asymptomatic, growing AMLs measuring >3 cm in diameter. Angiomyolipomas do not normally require surgery unless life-threatening bleeding is present.

Other options:

Renal cyst is a broader term that includes the cystic lesions of the kidney. They can be simple cysts that are benign. Complex or complicated cystic lesions need evaluation and can be malignant. Bosniak classification is used for renal cysts. Cysts appear as hypodense lesions (greyish) with a thin wall, with or without septations.

CT image showing a simple renal cyst:

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the most common malignant tumour of the kidney. It usually occurs in the age group 50-70 years and macroscopic hematuria is seen in about 60% of the cases. It is a differential for angiomyolipoma but it is important to note that macroscopic fat is almost always associated with ossification or calcification.

questions.text:
A young female patient with a history of renal calculi presents with bone pain and abdominal cramps. On investigation, multiple fractures and raised levels of serum calcium and PTH are noted. Which of the following will be the best investigation to arrive at a definitive diagnosis?

PTH- Parathormone
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation is suggestive of hyperparathyroidism. Sestamibi scan is the best investigation for parathyroid abnormalities. The most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism is parathyroid adenoma.

Sestamibi is a monovalent, lipophilic cation that passively diffuses across cell membranes and accumulates in mitochondria.

There are mainly two techniques used to differentiate sestamibi uptake by abnormal parathyroid and thyroid tissue:

  • Subtraction imaging - This method uses a dual radionu­clide approach with sestamibi and either iodine-123 or either 99mTc pertechnetate.
  • Dual-phase imaging - This method uses sesta­mibi alone with early and delayed imaging.

Sestamibi single-photon emission CT has become the most commonly used preoperative imaging study in parathyroid disease because of its improved spatial resolution.

The image below shows left inferior thyroid adenoma:

Sestamibi combined with computed tomography (CT) offers the advantage of detecting smaller parathyroid lesions that would otherwise be undetectable with sestamibi alone.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with chronic alcoholism presented with severe right-sided upper abdominal pain. On examination, her SOFA score was 3. An abdominal CT was done which is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the CT showing gas within the wall of the gallbladder is suggestive of emphysematous cholecystitis.

Emphysematous cholecystitis is a rare form of acute cholecystitis where gallbladder wall necrosis causes gas formation intramurally or intraluminally. 

This condition occurs most frequently in elderly males or patients with diabetes. Secondary infection of the gallbladder wall with gas-forming organisms such as Clostridium welchii/ C. perfringens leads to emphysematous cholecystitis, and aerobes such as Escherichia coli may also be isolated. Patients present with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and low-grade fever. Crepitus is present on physical examination.

On imaging, the air is seen in the gallbladder wall and/or biliary ducts, in the absence of abnormal communication with the gastrointestinal tract is seen.

Emphysematous cholecystitis has a high mortality rate due to the development of gangrene, perforation, and other complications. Hence, emergency cholecystectomy is indicated for the management of these patients. 

 

The given image shows a postoperative specimen of an emphysematous gallbladder along with an X-ray showing air in the gallbladder wall.

questions.text: A 27-year-old lady presented with pain and swelling in her knee. Histopathology of the lesion showed a large number of osteoclast-like giant cells seen scattered amidst round or spindle-shaped mononuclear cells. The stroma appeared well vascularized, with bands of fibrous tissue with areas of hemorrhage and collections of foamy macrophages interspersed in between. Which of the following x-rays belongs to this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical stem and characteristic histopathology findings are suggestive of a giant cell tumor (GCT), or osteoclastoma. The x-ray findings of GCT are seen in Image 2, which shows an expansile, eccentric, sub-articular lesion, with a soap-bubble appearance.

A GCT is typically seen on x-ray as an eccentric, lobulated, lytic lesion with non-sclerotic borders, giving a soap-bubble appearance. GCTs usually have little or no matrix calcification, new bone formation, or periosteal reaction. Tumors that extend into the soft tissues are seen as soft-tissue masses, which may be covered by a thin layer of sclerosis. They are usually located in the epiphysis of the long bone, but may also extend to the metaphysis. If malignant, the tumor appears as a lytic lesion with a sclerosing destructive tumor adjacent to it.

CT imaging estimates cortical bone involvement, and MRI shows an isointense or hypointense lesion on T1-weighted images.

GCTs are benign but locally aggressive tumors of the bone and are characterized by a proliferation of mononuclear cells, with scattered macrophages. They are most commonly seen at 20–45 years of age. GCTs may occasionally be associated with Paget’s disease of bone and focal dermal hypoplasia (Goltz syndrome).

They are seen in the epiphysis of long bones, more commonly the distal femur, proximal tibia, distal radius, and proximal humerus. Patients present with pain and a mass. 

Histologically, GCTs consist of a large number of osteoclast-like giant cells, with scattered, round, or spindle-shaped mononuclear cells. The tumor stroma is well-vascularized, with bands of cellular or collagenous fibrous tissue. Interposed areas of hemorrhage, hemosiderin, and foamy macrophages are seen.

The image below shows the histopathology of osteoclastoma.

Image 1: It shows Brodie's abscess, which is a small cavity in the bone with little or no periosteal reaction, seen in subacute osteomyelitis.

Image 3: It shows multiple osteochondromas around the knee joint. An osteochondroma is a common benign, cartilaginous neoplasm, seen more often in males during adolescent years. Pedunculated osteochondromas typically point away from the joint, towards the diaphysis.

Image 4: It shows osteosarcoma with a sunburst appearance. They appear as ill-defined, bone-forming lesions causing cortical destruction, periosteal reaction, and expansion into the soft tissues. Codman’s triangle may be visualized where new bone forms in response to periosteal elevation.

questions.solution:
The given CT image shows a simple renal cyst. The Bosniak classification system is used for the classification of renal cystic masses based on characteristics seen on contrast-enhanced CT. It is helpful in predicting malignancy risk and formulating a management plan.

Bosniak class Appearance Malignancy Management

Simple cyst : 

Rounded with imperceptible wall

 Not malignant No further workup required
2

Minimally complex: 

  • Size <1 mm with septa, thin calcifications

 

 Not malignant No further workup required

  • Size >3 cm
  • Increased number of septa
  • Minimally thickened with nodular/thick calcifications
 5% chance  Ultrasound/CT follow-up every 6 months

  • Complicated cysts, thickened septa
  • Nodular calcification/solid non-enhancing areas (appears hyperdense on CT)

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with regurgitation of undigested food, halitosis, and recurrent cough for a few months. He also mentioned the sensation of food being stuck in the throat. What is the investigation of choice to diagnose the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of a Zenker's diverticulum. The investigation of choice to diagnose Zenker’s diverticulum is a barium swallow.

A barium swallow study may show a diverticulum arising from the midline of the posterior wall of the distal pharynx near the pharyngoesophageal junction. The diverticulum is typically noted at the C5-6 level. The outpouching may be transient, sometimes referred to as a pharyngeal pouch. The pouch is best identified during swallowing and is best visualized on the lateral view. 

Since a majority of patients with a Zenker's diverticulum have a hiatal hernia and gastro-oesophageal reflux, the distal esophagus should also be evaluated.

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

questions.text: What is the earliest skull x-ray sign in a child with raised intracranial tension (ICT)?
questions.solution:
The earliest skull x-ray sign in a child with raised ICT is sutural diastasis. Another sign is the silver- or copper-beaten skull, which refers to prominent markings of convolution on the skull.

The images below are lateral and PA films of a child with raised ICT and marked suture diastasis (widening) involving the coronal and lambdoid sutures.

 The earliest skull x-ray sign in an adult with raised ICT is posterior clinoid erosion, which is followed by erosion of the dorsum sella.

Related Pearl: Intracranial Hypertension

Definition

Intracranial hypertension is pressure within the cranium above normal. Normal range of ICP is 5-15mm Hg. Levels above 20-25mm Hg are usually treated. 

Causes: Intracranial haemorrhage, brain tumors, head injury, meningitis, brain abscess, etc. 

Symptoms of raised ICT

  • Cushing’s triad – hypertension, bradycardia and respiratory depression
  • Headache, visual blurring due to papilloedema and abducent nerve palsy 
  • Focal symptoms may arise due to the local effects in patients with mass lesions or due to herniation.
  • Seizures
  • Stroke

Investigations

  • CT brain or MRI brain with gadolinium to rule out ICSOL 
  • Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in the presence of raised ICT due to the risk of coning.
  • Papilledema (as an indicator of ICT) should be ruled out before lumbar puncture.

Treatment

  • Dexamethasone
  • Ventriculotomy to remove CSF or ventriculoperitoneal shunt
  • Decompressive craniectomy
  • Surgical resection of ICSOL – by craniotomy or stereotactic radiosurgery
  • Whole brain radiation for multiple metastases causing raised ICT

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following chest radiograph findings according to the respective grades of sarcoidosis, in increasing order.

A. Pulmonary fibrosis

B. Lung parenchymal infiltrates and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy

C. Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy with right paratracheal node involvement

D. Parenchymal infiltrates without lymphadenopathy
questions.solution:
The chest radiograph is the preferred tool used to stage sarcoidosis.

Stage 1

 Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy (usually symmetrical); right paratracheal nodes often enlarged
Stage 2  Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and parenchymal infiltrates
Stage 3 Parenchymal infiltrates without bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy
Stage 4 Pulmonary fibrosis

 

The parenchymal infiltrates in sarcoidosis are predominantly seen in the upper lobe and appear as diffuse reticular infiltrates. However, focal infiltrates, acinar shadows, nodules, and cavitation may also be seen.

Garland triad is a lymph node enlargement pattern seen on the chest radiographs in sarcoidosis that involves: right paratracheal nodes, right hilar nodes, and left hilar nodes. It is also known as the 1-2-3 sign or Pawnbrokers sign (shown in the image below).

questions.text: A  54-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset of chest pain and breathing difficulty. On examination, there is tachypnea and tachycardia. Chest x-ray shows Westermark's sign and Hampton's hump. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the presence of Westermark's sign and Hampton's hump on radiography are suggestive of pulmonary embolism.

Pulmonary embolism is an embolic occlusion of the pulmonary arterial system. X-ray is neither sensitive nor specific for pulmonary embolism diagnosis. It is used to exclude differential diagnostic possibilities such as pneumonia and pneumothorax rather than directly diagnosing a pulmonary embolism. CT pulmonary angiography is the investigation of choice in pulmonary embolism.

Described chest radiographic signs include:

  • Fleishner's sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.
  • Westermark's sign is a chest x-ray finding in pulmonary embolism. It is defined by a hyperlucent area with decreased vascularity due to oligemia of the involved part of the lung.

Chest x-ray demonstrating Westermark sign:

 

  • Hampton's hump refers to the pleural-based, peripheral wedge-shaped opacity with its apex pointing towards the occluding vessel. It implies lung infarction and is usually not seen in the first 24 hours of pulmonary embolism.

 

  • ‘Knuckle’ or ‘sausage’ sign - It refers to dilatation of a central pulmonary artery due to occlusion by the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.
  • Palla’s sign - dilated right descending pulmonary artery

The image below shows Palla's sign:

 

  • Other secondary radiographic findings include elevated hemidiaphragm, pleural effusion, and plate-like atelectasis.

questions.text: A 70-year-old lady with recent-onset, progressive dementia presents with myoclonus. The brain imaging findings are shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD).

The imaging studies are diffusion-weighted imaging and T2-weighted-fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (T2-FLAIR) imaging. The findings of cortical ribboning and basal ganglia hyperintensity on the two abovementioned MRI modalities have a high sensitivity and specificity. This has diminished the need for brain biopsy in patients with suspected CJD.

CJD is a spongiform encephalopathy caused by a prion. It presents as rapidly progressive dementia and is usually fatal within 1 year of the onset of symptoms.

Symptoms are almost always rapidly progressive, and the clinical presentation includes the following:

  • Myoclonus
  • Higher cortical deficits
  • Psychiatric manifestations - depression, psychosis, and visual hallucinations
  • Profound dementia - memory loss, impaired judgment, intellectual decline
  • Visual impairment or cerebellar gait and coordination deficits in a few patients
  • Nonspecific prodromal symptoms - fatigue, sleep disturbance, weight, loss, headache, anxiety, vertigo, malaise, and ill-defined pain 
  • Extrapyramidal dysfunction - rigidity, masklike facies, choreoathetoid movements;
  • Seizures
  • Hypoesthesia
  • Supranuclear gaze palsy, optic atrophy

EEG shows repetitive, high-voltage, triphasic, and polyphasic sharp discharges in advanced cases. CSF analysis shows a positive assay for 14-3-3 protein. Brain biopsy shows the presence of prion protein scrapie (PrPSc).

Management is mainly supportive. 

Other options:

Option A: Dementia with Lewy bodies is the most common disorder to be mistaken for CJD. It has a subacute presentation with delirium, myoclonus, and extrapyramidal features. The absence of abnormalities on diffusion-weighted and T2-FLAIR MRI will almost always distinguish most dementias from CJD.

Option B: MRI in progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy reveals multifocal asymmetric, coalescing white matter lesions located in the periventricular region, in the centrum semiovale, parietal-occipital region, and in the cerebellum. These lesions show an increased signal on T2 and FLAIR. 

Option C: MRI in subacute sclerosing panencephalitis is usually normal in the early stages. Increased T2 signaling in the white matter of the brain is seen as the disease progresses.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old male with an on-and-off history of constipation now presents with complaints of severe abdominal pain, abdominal distension, and obstipation. He is stabilized before being sent for radiological investigations. Which of the following radiological findings would prompt you to consider a diagnosis of sigmoid volvulus in this patient?
  1. Bent inner tube sign on plain x-ray
  2. Whorl sign on CT
  3. Northern exposure sign on a supine abdominal x-ray
  4. Pseudokidney sign on ultrasonography
  5. Target sign on USG

choices.text: I, II, III, IV  are correct

questions.solution:
Bent inner tube sign on plain x-ray, Northern exposure sign on a supine abdominal x-ray, and Mesenteric whorl sign on CT would be consistent with sigmoid volvulus.

Volvulus is a condition in which the bowel becomes twisted on its mesenteric axis, resulting in partial or complete obstruction of the bowel and impairment of its blood supply. The condition usually affects the colon, most commonly the sigmoid colon. Less frequently, the right colon and terminal ileum (referred to as cecal volvulus), the cecum alone, and rarely, the transverse colon can also be affected.

This may present as acute or subacute intestinal obstruction. The patients complain of sudden onset severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and obstipation. The abdomen is generally markedly distended and tympanitic.

Plain abdominal X Rays typically reveal a markedly dilated sigmoid colon resembling a bent inner tube, with the apex in the right upper quadrant - Coffee bean sign or Bent inner tube sign. An air-fluid level may be visualized in the dilated loop of the colon, and the rectum usually does not contain gas. 

On a supine abdominal x-ray, the apex of the sigmoid volvulus is seen above (cranial to) the transverse colon, known as the Northern exposure sign. This sign is considered highly specific for sigmoid volvulus.

CT demonstrates a characteristic whorl sign caused due to the twisting of the mesentery and mesenteric vessels.

Treatment of the sigmoid volvulus involves appropriate resuscitation, followed by nonoperative decompression in most cases. Resection can be done as an elective procedure.

The radiograph below shows the 'coffee bean sign' or 'bent inner tube sign' of sigmoid volvulus.

Other options - Pseudokidney sign and target sign are seen on ultrasonography in cases of intussusception.

Target sign of intussusception, most likely seen in infants during the weaning period due to hypertrophy of the Peyer's patches. The target sign of intestinal intussusception is also known as the doughnut sign or bull's eye sign. The appearance is generated by concentric alternating echogenic and hypoechogenic bands. The echogenic bands are formed by mucosa and muscularis whereas the submucosa is responsible for the hypoechoic bands.

Ultrasound signs of intussusception include:

  • Target sign (Also known as the doughnut sign).
  • Pseudokidney sign: this is seen in the longitudinal section of the bowel. The edematous bowel resembles renal parenchyma and the mesentery which is dragged into the intussusception resembles renal hilum.
  • Crescent in a doughnut sign.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient presented with headaches, seizures, and focal neurologic deficits. MRI findings are shown in the image below. Considering the sign seen in the image, what is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of headache, seizures, focal neurological deficits, and the MRI showing a dural tail sign are suggestive of meningioma.

The dural tail sign refers to a linear, contrast-enhancing tail-like extension from the tumour, along the dura matter. It is most commonly seen in meningioma (present in about 60% of the cases). However, it may also be seen in the following non-meningiomatous lesions such as schwannoma, sarcoidosis, primary CNS lymphoma, metastasis, and chloroma.

The image given below shows axial (A) and sagittal (B) contrast-enhanced MRI images of the brain. The arrows point towards the thickening and enhancements of the dura, tapering away from the mass and resembling a tail (dural tail sign).

Radiological features of meningioma:

  • Angiography may reveal a spoke wheel appearance, or a dense, homogeneous, and persistent blush representing meningeal blood supply to the tumor.
  • CT usually reveals a hyperdense extra-axial mass with or without calcification.
  • MRI may show capping cysts, vasogenic edema, and a dural tail sign.
  • PET shows high uptake of 68Ga-DOTATOC, a somatostatin receptor-targeted ligand.

Other options:

Option A: Extradural hematoma refers to the collection of blood between the skull and dura mater. It appears as a lenticular, biconvex lesion in acute cases or as a crescentic-shaped lesion in chronic cases.

Option B: Subdural hematoma refers to the collection of blood between the dura and arachnoid mater. It appears as a crescentic concave in acute cases or an elliptical lesion in chronic cases.

Option C: Craniopharyngioma is a benign suprasellar tumor arising from squamous epithelial remnants of Rathke’s pouch. It is commonly located in the hypothalamic region. On MRI, it usually appears as a cystic lesion. It may also present as a mixed cystic or solid lesion. The solid components show intense contrast enhancement.

questions.text:
Match the following Intravenous pyelogram (IVP) findings and the conditions associated with them.
1) Cobra neck appearance a) Retroperitoneal fibrosis
2) Maiden waist sign b) Retrocaval ureter
3) Paintbrush appearance c) Ureterocele
4) Fishhook ureters d) Medullary sponge kidney
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b (option B).

IVP sign Condition
1. Cobra neck appearance c. Ureterocele
2. Maiden waist sign a. Retroperitoneal fibrosis
3. Paintbrush appearance d. Medullary sponge kidney
4. Fishhook ureters b. Retrocaval ureter 

 

Cobra neck appearance - It is also called the cobra head sign or the spring onion sign and is seen in the ureterocele. It refers to dilatation of the distal ureter, surrounded by a thin rim to the ureteric wall and bladder mucosa. It is seen in patients with an adult-type ureterocele. The cobra head appearance indicates an uncomplicated ureterocele.

 

Maiden waist deformity: It refers to the appearance of the medial deviation of bilateral ureters. This is typically seen in retroperitoneal fibrosis. In this condition, there is a medial drawing of the ureter due to the deposition of fibrous tissue in the lumbosacral junction. Due to the involvement of both ureters, the course of the medially-drawn ureters has an appearance of a narrow maiden waist, thus giving the name.

 

Paintbrush appearance - It refers to the appearance of dilated contrast-filled tubules within the renal medulla and is seen in the medullary sponge kidney. Another typical finding in medullary sponge kidney is the bouquet of flower appearance. 

Image of medullary sponge kidney showing paintbrush and bouquet of flower appearance:

 

Fish hook ureter: 

  • Right-sided fish hook ureter describes the appearance of the retrocaval ureter as the right ureter hooks behind the IVC, it has also been referred to as an S-shaped ureter.
  • Bilateral Fishhook ureters (J-shaped ureters or hockey stick ureters) describe the course of the distal ureter in patients with significant benign prostatic hypertrophy.

questions.text: What is the minimum amount of fluid that can be detected by this x-ray view?
questions.solution:
The shown x-ray view is the lateral decubitus view, which can identify as little as 10–25 mL of pleural fluid.

Minimum amount of fluid required to be detected in pleural effusion:

  • Lateral view – 75 mL pleural fluid
  • PA view – 100 to 200 mL pleural fluid
  • Lateral decubitus - <25 mL pleural fluid

A chest x-ray of pleural effusion is shown below. Arrow A shows fluid layering in the right pleural cavity. Arrow B shows the normal width of the lung in the cavity

 

Radiological signs of pleural effusion:

  • Left lateral decubitus chest radiograph demonstrating the presence of free pleural fluid
  • The amount of pleural fluid can be semi quantified by measuring A.
  • The first finding that appears in frontal view is blunting of costophrenic angle.
  • Ellis-S curve – Lateral border of the pleural fluid level is higher than the medial border.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child from a poor family is brought to the pediatric outpatient department with complaints of purpuric rash and pain in the limbs. Examination revealed bleeding from swollen gums and petechiae on the hard palate and tenderness on palpation of his extremities. On imaging, Pelkan spurs were seen on x-ray. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of pain in the limbs along with purpuric rash, bleeding gums, petechiae, and the x-ray finding of Pelkan spurs, is highly suggestive of scurvy.

Radiological findings in scurvy:

  • Frankel's line - Zone of provisional calcification at the growing metaphysis is dense, giving a white line called the Frankel's line.
  • Pelkan spurs - These are metaphyseal spurs formed due to fractures manifesting at the cortical margins. 
  • Wimberger’s ring sign - The sclerotic rim around the epiphysis forms this appearance.
  • Trummerfeld zone - Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line.

 

Scurvy:

Scurvy results from the deficiency of vitamin C and in this condition, there is the defective formation of connective tissue and collagen in the skin, bone, cartilage, dentine, and blood vessels which leads to their fragility.

Hemorrhagic manifestations of scurvy include petechiae, purpura, ecchymoses at pressure points, epistaxis, gum bleeding, and characteristic perifollicular hemorrhages. Other manifestations are poor wound and fracture healing, hyperkeratosis of hair follicles, arthralgia, and muscle weakness. It also results in defective osteoid formation. Costo-chondral separation leads to the formation of tender nodules, which are sharply angulated also known as the scorbutic rosary.

Other options:

Option A: Rickets presents with skeletal changes like bowing of legs and bone pain. Radiological features show cupping at metaphysics, fraying, and widening of the growth plate.

Option C: Osteogenesis imperfecta presents with the hallmark features of osteoporosis with increased fragility of bones along with blue sclera, dental fragility as well as hearing loss.

Option D: Osteopetrosis is also known as 'marble bone disease' where bones become sclerotic and thick, but their abnormal structure makes them weak and brittle.

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring/ Wimberger sign: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

The below image shows bowing of legs in rickets.

questions.text: A 40-year-old HIV patient presents with a productive cough with blood-stained sputum, evening rise of temperature, and weight loss for 3 weeks. His chest x-ray image is shown below.  What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an evening rise of temperature and productive cough for more than 2 weeks in an HIV patient and a chest x-ray image showing bilateral pulmonary infiltrates and cavity in the left apical region is highly suggestive of reactivation pulmonary tuberculosis (TB).

Pulmonary TB is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Pulmonary TB due to exogenous (new infection) or endogenous (reactivation of a dormant primary lesion) infection in a sensitized individual is called post-primary or reactivation or secondary or adult-type TB.

The apical and posterior segments of the upper lobe and superior segments of the lower lobe are most commonly involved in post-primary TB due to increased ventilation in these segments than in the lower zones.

Patients often present with fever, productive cough, blood-streaked sputum, night sweats, malaise, loss of appetite, and weight loss.

Investigations: 

  1. Sputum microscopy:
    • Ziehl-Neelsen staining - the presence of acid-fast bacilli
    • Auramine fluorescence staining
  2. Sputum culture:
    • Sold media (Lowenstein-Jensen medium) or liquid media (MGIT)
  3. Catridge-based nucleic acid amplification test (CB-NAAT) is currently the first-line preferred diagnostic test.
  4. Radiograph imaging - Chest x-ray and CT chest 

Radiological findings include ill-defined opacification in the upper lobes, consolidation, collapse, and cavitation.

  1. Typically, the disease is parenchymal without nodal enlargement.
  2. Cavitation is a distinguishing feature of post-primary TB;
    • Typical cavities are thick-walled and irregular.
    • Air-fluid levels are uncommon in TB. The presence of air-fluid levels indicates superadded infections.
  3. Upper-lobe involvement with cavitation and the absence of lymphadenopathy distinguishes post-primary TB from primary TB.

Complications of pulmonary TB:

  • Massive hemoptysis
  • Cor pulmonale
  • Fibrosis/emphysema
  • Pleural effusion
  • Lung/pleural calcification 
  • Aspergilloma/chronic aspergillosis
  • Obstructive airways disease
  • Bronchiectasis
  • Bronchopleural fistula

The image below shows chest x-ray findings of a post-primary TB with a cavity (black arrows) in the right upper lobe and bilateral pulmonary infiltrates (white triangles) in the apical regions.

Option A:

Aspergilloma or fungal ball is a late manifestation of chronic cavitary pulmonary aspergillosis (CPA) caused by Aspergillus species. A fungal ball is formed within the pulmonary cavity of CPA by the peeled-off inner layer of the cavity. 

Patients present with chronic features of fatigue, weight loss, cough, hemoptysis, and wheezing. However, clinical features such as foul-smelling sputum and night sweats are more commonly observed in TB, which helps in differentiating the two conditions.

Chest x-ray shows a spherical or ovoid mass within a cavity. The mass is mobile. CT demonstrates a rounded mass within a cavity. Monod sign refers to the air that surrounds an aspergilloma in a pre-existing pulmonary cavity.

Images below show Chest x-ray and CT findings in aspergilloma.

Option C:

Loculated pleural effusion:

A pleural effusion is the excessive accumulation of fluid in the pleural space. Loculated effusions occur most commonly in association with conditions that cause intense pleural inflammation, such as empyema, hemothorax, and tuberculosis. Fissural loculations mimic tumor tissue and are most commonly seen in congestive heart failure.

Patients present with typical pleuritic chest pain that increases on deep inspiration, coughing, sneezing, dyspnea, and a dry cough. Physical signs of loculated pleural effusion include reduced tactile fremitus, dullness on percussion, and diminished or absent breath sounds. Shifting dullness is absent in loculated effusions.

Chest x-ray shows blunting of the costophrenic and cardiophrenic angles. It also shows a homogenous opacity, which could be lateral or lamellar, mediastinal, apical, subpulmonic, or fissural (biconvex opacities). Loculated effusions are confirmed by lateral decubitus x-ray or USG.

The chest x-ray below shows a left-sided lamellar loculated pleural effusion.

Option D:

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) is caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii that is an opportunistic pathogen that is an important cause of pneumonia in immunocompromised hosts, particularly those with HIV infection, and follows a human-to-human transmission.

Patients with PCP generally present with fever, dyspnea, and cough that is usually non-productive. It ultimately results in respiratory distress and death.

Chest x-ray imaging shows a normal film if the disease is suspected early or diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates that are perihilar and symmetric. High-resolution CT shows ground-glass opacities.
