questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about conditions required for acute radiation syndrome?

choices.text: Radiation dose must be large i.e greater than 70 rads.
The dose must be mostly internal.
Bone marrow suppression occurs earlier than neurovascular effects.
The dose must have been delivered in a short time.

questions.solution:
Acute radiation syndrome after deposition of radioactive materials inside the body is extremely rare. The dose must be external.

Acute radiation syndrome, also called radiation toxicity or radiation sickness, is an acute illness caused by irradiation of the entire body by a high dose of penetrating radiation in a very short period of time. The major cause of this syndrome is the depletion of immature parenchymal stem cells in specific tissues.

Stages of Acute Radiation Syndrome (ARS)

The prodromal phase: This phase is marked by non-specific symptoms like nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. Early and persistent symptoms predict severity.

Latent phase: The patient looks and feels generally healthy for a few hours or even up to a few weeks. In severe cases, this phase may be absent.

Manifest illness phase: Symptoms depend the radiation dose. Tissues with greater rates of cellular division are most radiosensitive, and hence the hematopoietic and gastrointestinal systems are the most affected.

Recovery phase or Death: The recovery phase is seen after the manifest stage when the patient recovers from the acute exposure. The time taken for recovery depends on the severity of the injury and the organ system affected. 

Syndrome    Dose Prodromal Stage  Latent Stage Manifest Illness Stage Recovery/Death
Hematopoietic (Bone marrow)  >0.7 Gy (>70 rads) (mild symptoms may occur at doses as low as 0.3 Gy or 30 rads) 

 

  • Symptoms are anorexia, nausea and vomiting.
  • Onset occurs 1 hour to 2 days after exposure.
  • Stage lasts for minutes to days.  
  • Stem cells in bone marrow are dying, although patient may appear and feel well.
  • Stage lasts 1 to 6 weeks. 

 

  • Symptoms are anorexia, fever, and malaise.
  • Drop in all blood cell counts occurs for several weeks.
  • Primary cause of death is infection and hemorrhage.
  • Survival decreases with increasing dose.
  • Most deaths occur within a few months after exposure.  

 

  • In most cases, bone marrow cells will begin to repopulate the marrow.
  • There should be full recovery for a large percentage of individuals from a few weeks up to two years after exposure.

  • The LD50/60 is about 2.5 to 5 Gy (250 to 500 rads).

questions.text: A 20-year-old man sustained a sudden head injury as a result of which the bridging dural veins were injured. Which of the following appearance is likely to be seen in the CT Brain of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of an acute subdural hematoma, and the classical appearance likely to be seen in this patient is a crescent-shaped hyperdense lesion.

Subdural hematoma (SDH) refers to the hemorrhage between the dura and arachnoid mater, and most commonly, it results from injury to the bridging dural veins. The causes of SDH include trauma, anticoagulants, antiplatelets, alcohol abuse, and battered baby syndrome.

Acute subdural hematomas are crescent-shaped. They can cross suture lines, but they do not cross the tentorium or falx. In a non-contrast CT Brain, the acute lesions are hyperdense; subacute lesions are isodense; and chronic lesions are hypodense.

During the subacute phase with isodense lesions, the findings that are suggestive of subdural hematoma are gyral effacement and ventricular compression on the affected side and midline shift away from the affected side.

The below image shows acute subdural hematoma with a hyperdense crescentic lesion in the right posterior parietal region between the brain and the skull and a midline shift to left.

Other options:

Lentiform-shaped hyperdense lesion is seen in acute extradural hematoma. Lentiform-shaped hypodense lesion is seen in a chronic extradural hematoma. The crescent-shaped hypodense lesion is seen in chronic subdural hematoma.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of new-onset chest pain 1 week after an episode of viral infection. The lateral view chest radiograph shows an oreo cookie sign. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the lateral view chest radiograph showing an Oreo cookie sign are suggestive of pericardial effusion.

On lateral radiographs of the chest, a three-layered appearance is seen with a vertical opaque line (pericardial fluid) in the center, a vertical lucent line (pericardial fat) anteriorly, and a similar vertical lucent line (epicardial fat) posteriorly. This resembles an Oreo cookie.

The above image shows pericardial fluid (yellow asterisk) outlined by epicardial fat (blue arrows) and pericardial fat (orange arrows), giving a three-layered appearance, known as an Oreo cookie sign. 

A plain PA chest x-ray shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette. There is effacement of the normal cardiac borders, development of a ‘flask’ or ‘water bottle’ cardiac configuration, and bilateral hilar overlay which are features of pericardial effusion. It is also known as a money bag or leather bottle-shaped heart.

The investigation of choice is echocardiography as it allows localization and estimation of the quantity of pericardial fluid. CT and MRI are indicated when echocardiography is inconclusive, when the effusion is loculated or hemorrhagic or when there is pericardial thickening.

Pericardial effusion is usually associated with chest pain and/or the ECG changes of pericarditis (widespread ST elevation, often with upward concavity). If the effusion is large, the ECG may show electrical alternans. Heart sounds may be faint, friction rub, and the apical impulse may not be audible. It may occur following viral or infective pericarditis.

Note: Double Oreo cookie sign: Superior labral anterior posterior sign (SLAP tear) of the glenoid labrum.

questions.text: A young male presents with pain in his right shoulder. He slipped during his treadmill workout and tried to hold on to the side rails. The x-ray image obtained is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a patient who developed pain in his shoulder after forced abduction of his shoulder after a fall. The x-ray shows the head of the humerus is below the glenoid and the shaft in the abducted position. This is suggestive of an inferior shoulder dislocation, also known as luxatio erecta. 

It is rare and occurs when the arm is forcefully pulled up when in full abduction (hyper-abduction force) due to high-energy trauma. The patient will present with the arm locked in almost full abduction.

questions.text: The characteristic radiographic finding shown in the image below is ________.
questions.solution:
The radiograph shows the spinnaker sail sign, which is seen in pneumomediastinum.

Spinnaker sail sign is a chest x-ray finding in neonates with pneumomediastinum. The elevated thymus is outlined by air, and each lobe of the thymus is displaced laterally (because of air in the mediastinum), producing the appearance of spinnaker sails.

Other radiographic findings in pneumomediastinum:

  • Ring around the artery sign- It occurs due to air around the pulmonary artery.
  • Continuous diaphragm sign - In AP view, the air trapped posterior to the pericardium produces an appearance of continuous collection of air.
  • Extrapleural sign - Air extends laterally between the parietal pleura and the diaphragm.
  • Tubular artery sign - It occurs due to air around the major branches of the aorta.
  • Double bronchial wall sign - It occurs due to air around the bronchus, producing a clear depiction of the bronchial wall.

Three main causes of pneumomediastinum:

  1. Alveolar rupture with dissection of air into the mediastinum
  2. Perforation or rupture of the esophagus, trachea, or main bronchi
  3. Dissection of air from the neck or the abdomen into the mediastinum

Other options:

Option A: Cupola sign is a supine chest/abdominal radiograph finding in pneumoperitoneum. It is seen in the supine position as the gas within the abdominal cavity rises and accumulates underneath the central tendon of the diaphragm in the midline. It appears as a lucency overlying the lower thoracic vertebral bodies.

 

Option B: Falciform ligament sign is seen in pneumoperitoneum and refers to the falciform ligament being outlined by the free abdominal gas.

 

Option C: Rigler’s sign is also known as double-wall sign, and it is an abdominal radiograph finding in pneumoperitoneum. As seen in the image, both the inner and outer walls of the bowel are visible.

questions.text: A 17-year-old female presents with severe cramping in her legs while exercising in the gym. She has been experiencing these symptoms for the past few months. On examination, radial pulse is 88 beats/min, and distal pulses of the lower limb are barely palpable. Blood pressure is 144/88 mmHg in the right arm and 108/70 mmHg in the right leg. The obtained chest x-ray image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and chest x-ray showing notching of ribs strongly point towards the diagnosis of coarctation of the aorta. 

Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital heart defect characterized by the narrowing of the thoracic aorta near the insertion of the ductus arteriosus. According to the site of constriction, it is classified into the following types:

  • Preductal: constriction proximal to the ductus arteriosus (infantile type)
  • Postductal: constriction distal to the ductus arteriosus (adult type)

Clinical presentation of coarctation of the aorta depends on the extent of constriction and age at the presentation:

  • Infants with coarctation of the aorta may present with tachypnea, lethargy, failure to thrive, or overt congestive heart failure. Clinical signs classically worsen after the closure of ductus arteriosus.
  • Adults may present with non-specific symptoms, such as headaches and nose bleeds, or claudication of the lower limbs, which is experienced as cramping pain that increases on exertion.

Coarctation of the aorta is associated with the bicuspid aortic valve, berry aneurysm, and Turner syndrome.

Physical examination findings:

  • Bounding upper limb pulses (radial, carotid) and weak lower limb pulses (femoral, popliteal, posterior tibial, and dorsalis pedis)
  • Increased radio-femoral delay
  • Hypertension in upper limbs and increased difference in blood pressure between upper and lower limbs
  • Continuous like murmur (due to collaterals)
  • Systolic ejection click and systolic ejection murmur in the left upper sternal border (due to bicuspid aortic valve)

Radiologic findings on chest x-ray:

  • Figure 3 sign - It is pathognomonic of coarctation of the aorta. It occurs due to the indentation of the aorta at the site of coarctation and pre- and post-stenotic dilatation along the left para-mediastinum.
  • Notching of ribs - This occurs due to rib erosion by dilated collateral vessels.
  • Dilated left subclavian artery and dilated ascending aorta

It can be diagnosed using x-ray, CT or MRI, or cardiac catheterization. It is definitively managed surgically or with balloon dilation. 

The figure of 3 sign is shown in the image below. 

Other options:

Option A- Total anomalous pulmonary venous return is a clinical entity in which the pulmonary veins fail to enter the left atrium and instead drain into the right atrium or its systemic venous tributaries. It is classified into 4 types: supra-cardiac, cardiac, infracardiac, and mixed types. On chest radiography, the supra-cardiac type shows a characteristic snowman or figure of 8 appearance.

Option B- Takayasu arteritis is a granulomatous vasculitis involving the aorta and the pulmonary arteries, resulting in varying degrees of stenosis, occlusion, or dilatation. It can result in diminished or absent pulses, limb claudications, hypertension due to renal artery stenosis. Chest radiograph may reveal oligemic lung fields if pulmonary artery involvement occurs.

Option C- Ebstein anomaly is characterized by an abnormal tricuspid valve that is displaced downwards into the right ventricle. Hence, a part of the right ventricle is now located above the tricuspid valve. This is called atrialization of the ventricle. There can be associated tricuspid regurgitation with or without stenosis. Chest x-ray findings depend on the degree to which the tricuspid valve is displaced downwards. There is usually an enlarged right atrium, resulting in severe right-sided cardiomegaly, which gives a box-shaped heart appearance.

questions.text: A barium enema study of a patient is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given barium enema study is showing a saw tooth appearance suggestive of colonic diverticulosis. Both single and double-contrast barium enemas are able to demonstrate diverticula as barium-filled outpouchings.

Colonic diverticula are almost all false diverticula i.e., mucosa herniating through a defect in the muscularis and covered by overlying serosa (where present). This herniation typically occurs where nutrient arteries enter the colon, and therefore, are more common on the mesenteric side of the colon. Colonic diverticula are most common in the sigmoid colon and, to a lesser extent, in the descending colon.

questions.text: An 18-year-old female patient came with a complaint of a palpable painless mass in the left breast. On examination, the mass was highly mobile and rubbery in consistency. Ultrasound of the left breast was performed and the finding is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette along with the above image is suggestive of fibroadenoma of breast. It presents as a painless, palpable lump and is rubbery in consistency. The ultrasound image depicts a well-circumscribed oval mass with uniform hypoechogenicity. 

Fibroadenoma is one of the aberrations of normal development and involution of the breast (ANDI). These are the most common benign masses of the breast. The most common age group affected is 15-25 years (early reproductive period) with a peak incidence in the second decade.

It arises from hyperplasia of a single lobule and presents as a well-circumscribed, smooth, firm, non-tender, freely mobile mass (mouse in the breast). It is a biphasic tumor consisting of fibroblastic stroma and epithelium-lined gland. On mammograms, they present as rounded or oval masses with coarse calcifications (popcorn calcifications).

The image below shows popcorn calcification:

Excision is not advised unless there is suspicious histology on fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC). Giant fibroadenomas are >5 cm in size, common in adolescent girls, and require excision by submammary incision.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old male patient complained of pain after an injury to his left knee while playing football. MRI showed a bucket-handle tear of the medial meniscus. The anterior cruciate ligament was intact. Which of the following radiographic findings best describes this condition?

(PCL- posterior cruciate ligament)
questions.solution:
The double PCL sign is the radiographic finding seen on a sagittal MRI image in a bucket-handle medial meniscal tear with an intact anterior cruciate ligament.

Double PCL sign: Here, the bucket handle fragment of the torn meniscus is seen as a low-signal structure lying parallel to the posterior cruciate ligament (PCL), mimicking a second smaller PCL.

A bucket-handle tear occurs when there is a vertical split in the meniscus, and the separated fragment of the meniscus remains attached in the front and back. The medial meniscus is involved in 80% of the cases. 

An intact anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) is required to appreciate the double PCL sign in medial meniscal tears as it prevents the flipped meniscal fragment from further lateral movement.

In very few cases, the double PCL sign is seen with bucket-handle tears involving the lateral meniscus.

Meniscal tears can be horizontal and vertical.

Horizontal tears are frequently degenerative in nature and asymptomatic. Joint fluid may escape through this tear and form a parameniscal cyst.

Vertical tears can be of two types: longitudinal and radial.

Longitudinal tears:

  • They lie within the substance of the menisci and track circumferentially.
  • It usually involves the periphery of the meniscus, where the blood supply is better, and may heal spontaneously.

Radial tears:

  • It extends radially from the free edges into the meniscus, and it can be of several forms.
  • Parrot -beak tear: Small oblique slit-like radial tear
  • Ghost meniscus sign: It refers to the MRI appearance of a complete radial tear, usually involving the posterior root of the meniscus. It is so called because the meniscus disappears and then reappears like a "ghost" on consecutive sagittal sequences. 

Note: The double Oreo cookie sign is seen in injuries to the glenoid labrum. (option D)

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman has the following flow pattern of umbilical arteries on a Doppler study. What does this pattern indicate?
questions.solution:
The given Doppler image indicates normal diastolic flow in the umbilical arteries.

Umbilical artery vessels are characterized by forward, low-resistance flow. As gestation increases, there is a gradual fall in all the resistance indices, so the amount of forward diastolic flow increases. S/D ratio decreases as the period of gestation increases (S represents the peak systolic flow or velocity, and D indicates the end-diastolic flow or velocity).

Abnormal flow patterns in the umbilical artery:

  • Reduced end-diastolic flow: Uteroplacental insufficiency.
  • Absent end-diastolic flow: Fetal compromise (terminate the pregnancy by cesarean section if gestational age is >34 weeks).
  • Reverse end-diastolic flow: Impending doom of death (terminate pregnancy irrespective of gestational age).

Middle cerebral artery: This will show increased diastolic velocity in fetus with hypoxemia.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old obese woman was planned for CECT abdomen with urografin. She had presented with signs of severe dehydration, raised serum creatinine levels, and features of diabetic nephropathy. Which among the following is not a risk factor for contrast-induced nephropathy in this patient?

CECT - Contrast-enhanced computed tomography
questions.solution:
Obesity is not a risk factor for contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) in this patient. All the other factors are risk factors for CIN making this patient unfit for a CECT.

Contrast-induced nephropathy is defined as a 25% or 0.5 mg/dL increase from the baseline value of serum creatinine within 48-72 hours of intravenous contrast administration. It occurs due to tubular damage and as a result, the patient develops non-oliguric transient nephropathy.

Risk factors for contrast medium-induced nephropathy:

Patient-related

Procedure-related
  • eGFR <60 mL/min/1.73 m2 before intra-arterial administration
  • eGFR <45 mL/min/1.73 m2 before intravenous administration
  • Patient conditions that increase the risk:
    • Diabetic nephropathy
    • Dehydration
    • Congestive heart failure (NYHA grade 3–4) and low LVEF
    • Recent myocardial infarction (<24 h)
    • Intra-aortic balloon pump
    • Peri-procedural hypotension
    • Low hematocrit level
    • Age over 70
    • Concurrent administration of nephrotoxic drugs
    • Known or suspected acute renal failure

 

  
  • Intra-arterial administration of contrast medium
  • High-osmolality agents (Urografin)
  • Large doses of contrast medium
  • Multiple contrast medium administrations within a few days

 

 Side effects of iodinated contrast material include:

  • Idiosyncratic anaphylactoid reaction - patient develops bronchospasm and hypotension
  • Dose-dependent side effect – contrast-induced nephropathy seen especially with the use of high osmolar agents

Prevention of contrast-induced nephropathy:

  • IV fluids (isotonic saline or sodium bicarbonate) started 1 hour before and continued for at least 3-6 hours after the procedure
  • Low volume low osmolar contrast should be used
  • N-acetyl cysteine may be given prior to contrast exposure 

Note: In a patient on metformin, having deranged RFT, metformin must be stopped before administering the contrast. Otherwise, it can precipitate lactic acidosis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old farmer presents with complaints of shortness of breath and productive cough with orange mucus plugs for the past 2-3 weeks. His symptoms began after exposure to plant waste. He has a history of bronchial asthma and examination revealed rhonchi. Chest X-ray of the patient is shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the chest X-ray showing the finger-in-glove appearance are suggestive of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA).

Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is a hypersensitivity reaction involving the major airways. It is most commonly seen in patients with longstanding asthma. It can also be associated with cystic fibrosis. The condition is diagnosed in younger patients usually before 40 years of age. The patient typically presents with atopic symptoms. Sometimes expectorant cough with orange mucus plugs may be seen.

Radiographic findings in ABPA include:

  • Lobar collapse
  • Non-segmental areas of opacities commonly involving the upper lobe
  • Branching thick tubular opacities due to distended bronchi filled with fungus and mucus - Finger-in-glove appearance 
  • Pulmonary cavitation is rarely seen

Other features of aspergillus infection:

Aspergilloma: Aspergillomas are mass-like fungus balls that are typically composed of Aspergillus fumigatus and are a non-invasive form of pulmonary aspergillosis. Aspergillomas occur in patients with normal immunity but structurally abnormal lungs, with pre-existing cavities. The most common underlying condition is pulmonary tuberculosis. Radiographic findings of aspergilloma include:

  • Air crescent sign - The fungal ball can be seen on both plain film and CT as an intracavitary mass surrounded by a crescent of air.
  • The mass usually moves within the cavity when the patient moves and this sign is called the Monod sign.

Angioinvasive aspergillosis: It is seen in immunocompromised individuals, especially in patients with neutropenia. Halo sign is the typical CT finding in these patients.

  • The halo sign in chest imaging is a feature seen on HRCT where ground glass opacity surrounds a pulmonary nodule or mass and represents hemorrhage.

Other options:

Option A- Bronchiectasis is characterized by local and irreversible dilatation of bronchi. Radiographic findings are:

  • Tramline appearance is seen in chest X-rays.
  • Ring or curvilinear opacities on end-on appearance.
  • CT shows bronchial dilatation and lack of tapering of bronchial lumen. It is the cardinal sign.
  • Signet ring sign - Internal diameter of the bronchi is greater than the adjacent pulmonary artery.

Option B- Blastomycosis is a chronic infection, characterized by the formation of suppurative and granulomatous lesions, especially in the lungs and skin. The pulmonary disease resembles TB or histoplasmosis. There can be focal or diffuse consolidation, miliary lesions, or abscess formation.

 

Option C- Pulmonary tuberculosis chest radiograph typically shows upper lobe infiltrates with cavities. In immunocompromised individuals like in HIV patients, there can be lower zone infiltrates without cavity formation. In disseminated TB miliary reticulonodular patterns may be seen.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with 8-month history shortness of breath and non-productive cough. On physical examination, fine crackles are heard bilaterally. Pulmonary function tests show an FVC of 78% and FEV1/FVC ratio of 92%. CT scan of the chest is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pulmonary fibrosis is the most likely diagnosis in this patient given the symptoms of shortness of breath and persistent nonproductive cough, bilateral inspiratory crackles, pulmonary function test (PFT) results, and imaging findings.

The image shows the presence of honeycombing (black arrows), traction bronchiectasis (white arrow), and a reticular pattern (black dotted arrows). The lesions are typically located along subpleural regions.

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is the most common cause of interstitial lung disease (ILD) of unknown cause. It is defined as a progressive fibrosing interstitial pneumonia of unknown etiology, occurring in adults. It is associated with a histological or radiological pattern known as usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP). UIP is the typical pathological finding in patients with suspected IPF.

Patients with UIP typically present in their sixth and seventh decades of life. Men are affected more commonly than women. PFTs in patients with pulmonary fibrosis show a restrictive pattern, which is characterized by decreased total lung capacity (TLC), forced vital capacity (FVC), residual volumes (RV), and a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio of >0.7.

High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) demonstrates a characteristic pattern of peripheral (subpleural) and bibasilar reticular opacities associated with architectural distortion, including honeycomb changes and traction bronchiectasis.

Classification of ILD (based on the histopathological pattern observed on lung biopsy)

Histologic pattern Clinical syndrome
Usual interstitial pneumonia Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis
Desquamative interstitial Pneumonia Desquamative interstitial pneumonia
Acute interstitial pneumonia Hamman–Rich syndrome
Bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP) Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia
Non-specific interstitial pneumonia Non-specific interstitial pneumonia
Respiratory bronchiolitis–associated lung disease Respiratory bronchiolitis– associated interstitial lung disease

Related Pearl: HRCT Findings in Interstitial Lung Diseases

Idiopathic interstitial lung diseases

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis / Usual interstitial pneumonia
    • Honeycombing
    • Reticular shadows
    • Traction bronchiectasis
    • Complete loss of lung architecture
    • Absence of other nonspecific findings (ground-glass opacities, nodules, cysts, consolidations)
  • Non-specific interstitial pneumonia
    • Extensive ground-glass opacities
    • Sub pleural sparing (specific, but not seen always)
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP)
    • Patchy consolidation with air bronchogram
    • Reverse halo/ Atoll sign: Ground glass area surrounded by peripheral consolidation (as shown below in red arrows)
  • Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP)
    • Thin-walled cysts (shown below in red arrows)
    • Centrilobular nodules 
    • Ground glass opacities
  •  Respiratory bronchiolitis related interstitial lung disease
    • Centrilobular ground-glass nodules
    • Bronchial wall thickening
  • Acute interstitial pneumonia
    • Diffuse patchy ground-glass opacities
  • Desquamated interstitial pneumonia
    • Patchy ground-glass opacities 

Other forms of ILDs

  • Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
    • Regular thin-walled cysts
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP)
    • Ground-glass opacification with superimposed septal thickening, known as “crazy paving”
    • It is characteristic but not diagnostic
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCH)
    • Bilateral irregular shaped cysts with nodules, predominantly in the upper lobe.
